filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of electronic editions of Blake's illustrations to works by William Hayley, including his Essay on Sculpture, the broadside ballad Little Tom the Sailor, The Triumphs of Temper, The Life and Posthumous Writings of William Cowper, and The Life of George Romney. We are also republishing Blake’s etched and engraved illustrations to Designs to a Series of Ballads, Written by William Hayley (1802) and Hayley’s Ballads (1805). The designs and engraved texts of both sets of Ballads illustrations, as well as the new material now being published, are fully searchable.
In late 1799, William Hayley was seeking an engraver to illustrate his poem Essay on Sculpture. Possibly on the advice of the sculptor John Flaxman, Hayley commissioned Blake to produce three plates. In July 1800, Blake spent much of July working on the final plate, an engraving of Hayley’s deceased son, Thomas, in Hayley’s library in the coastal village of Felpham, West Sussex. During these weeks, Hayley persuaded Blake to relocate from London to Felpham to work on a number of graphic projects. Disenchanted with his failure to secure commercial engraving work in London, Blake enthusiastically took up Hayley’s offer.
The works now published and republished include all of Blake’s commercial engravings executed for Hayley during the three-year period Blake and his wife Catherine spent in Felpham. In addition, the Blake Archive is publishing two more engravings Blake worked on for Hayley after the Blakes had returned to London in September 1803. These plates were commissioned to illustrate Hayley’s The Life of George Romney (1809). Only one of these plates, Sketch of a Shipwreck after Romney, was included in the published biography. The other, a portrait engraving of Romney, was rejected and, until very recently, has not been seen since the 1939 Blake exhibition in Philadelphia.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design depicts a weather house containing two outdoor vignettes. Below the weather house is a roundel containing three hares. At the top of the design is a structure with a thatched roof and three trees that form the vertical supports. Leafy vines wrap around the center and right tree. The vine on the right tree extends to the right side and top of the thatched roof. The vignette on the right side of the weather house depicts a female in a long gown, facing forward. She stands on tip toe on the upper edge of a see-saw and her hair is in a bun. With her right hand, she is holding her gown to form a basket, which contains fruit or vegetables. In her left hand she is holding a round fruit. Behind her and to the right is a cottage with two windows, a central door and a thatched roof. A pathway leads up to the cottage door. To the left of the cottage are trees. Behind the female and to the left are at least three sheep, two of which are grazing. Behind the sheep are tree tops and a large hill. The sun is emerging from behind the hill. The vignette on the left side of the weather house depicts a male standing on the lower edge of the see-saw. The male faces left, in profile and is wearing a long coat and a broad-rimmed hat. The male holds a walking stick in his right hand. His left arm is bent across his chest. His left foot is on tip toe indicating that he is walking. Behind and to the right of the man, is a large mountain above which are dark clouds. Directly behind the man is a large body of water, possibly the sea, with a shore to the right. Diagonal lines indicate that it is raining. The weather house stands on a two-tiered plinth. Below the plinth are leaf and flower bearing garlands that drape onto a roundel containing a rural scene. Within the roundel are three hares. The rightmost hare (Bess) is lying on the ground, facing left, with its ears pointed upward. The leftmost hare (Puss) is also lying on the ground, but in a more contracted position and its ears are flat against its body. The third hare (Tiney) is running above them. To the right of the hares is the twisting trunk of a leafy tree. Below the hares is grass. Above the hares is a hill surrounded by vegetation, including trees and bushes. On top of the hill is a cottage with a visible window and a chimney issuing smoke. The cottage is surrounded by trees and bushes.

component.illusobjdesc: At the top of the design is a structure with a thatched roof and three trees that form the vertical supports. Leafy vines wrap around the center and right tree. The vine on the right tree extends to the right side and top of the thatched roof.

The vignette on the right side of the weather house depicts a female in a long gown, facing forward. She may be wearing a hat. She stands on tip toe on the upper edge of a see-saw and her hair is in a bun. With her right hand, she is holding her gown to form a basket, which contains fruit or vegetables. In her left hand she is holding a round fruit.
Both the female and male appear to be standing on a see-saw.
Behind the woman and to the right is a cottage with two windows, a central door and a thatched roof. A pathway leads up to the cottage door.
Behind the female and to the left are at least three sheep, two of which are grazing.

The vignette on the left side of the weather house depicts a male standing on the lower edge of the see-saw. The male faces left, in profile and is wearing a long coat with a collar turned up and a broad-rimmed hat. The male holds a walking stick in his right hand. His left arm is bent across his chest. His left foot is on tip toe indicating that he is walking.
Directly behind the man is a large body of water, possibly the sea or a lake, with a shore to the right. Diagonal lines indicate that it is raining.
The weather house stands on a two-tiered plinth. Below the plinth are leaf and flower bearing garlands and ribbons that loop and drape onto a roundel.

Within the roundel are three hares. The rightmost hare (Bess) is lying on the ground, facing left, with its ears pointed upward. The leftmost hare (Puss) is also lying on the ground, but in a more contracted position and its ears are flat against its body. It may be asleep. The third hare (Tiney) is running above them. To the right of the hares is the twisting trunk of a leafy tree, possibly ivy. Below the hares is grass.

Above the hares is a hill surrounded by vegetation, including trees and bushes. On top of the hill is a cottage with a visible window and a chimney issuing smoke. The cottage is surrounded by trees and bushes. There are also hills behind and to the left of the cottage. There are clouds above the cottage and hills.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design depicts the interior of a church, containing a tomb. A large Norman arch frames the scene. On the left of the arch is a column or pillar that runs from the stone floor to the ceiling. Within the arch are decorative pilasters that begin at the mid-point of the arch. Beyond the arch is a rectangular tomb behind a low metal fence or railing. To the left of the tomb is another arch with a pilaster. This arch forms a doorway to another part of the church. On top of the tomb, occupying a central position is a raised plinth. On top of the plinth are two books standing with their spines outward. The slimmer volume leans against the thicker volume. The books are covered by a large drooping laurel leaf. On the side of the tomb, beneath the books is a large white (marble) plaque with an indecipherable inscription. Above the tomb is a large Norman-style, stained-glass window that sits in a shallow casement. Above the window, there are parts of an ornamental ceiling.

desc.objtitle: A Sketch of the Monument Erected in the Church of East Dereham in Norfolk In Memory of William Cowper Esqre, Object 6 (Bentley 468.6)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design depicts the marble monument that adorns William Cowper's tomb. The monument consists of marble plaque containing an inscribed epitaph by William Hayley. Above the inscription is a plinth. There are two books located centrally on the plinth. The books face spine outward. The slimmer of the two volumes is Cowper's most popular work, "The Task," and leans against the thicker of the books. This is the "Holy Bible." A large laurel branch drapes over the books forming a arch.
